channel.title: BBC News - World
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Afghan crisis: Chaos as Europeans scramble to evacuate Kabul
item.description: Several countries rush to fly people out, as the Dutch government is criticised for reacting slowly.

item.title: Lithuania says Belarus officers illegally pushed migrants over border
item.description: Video shows 12 Belarusian officers in riot gear as migrants scramble towards Lithuanian territory.

item.title: Haiti earthquake: Death toll reaches nearly 2,000
item.description: A few dozen survivors have been pulled alive from under the rubble but many are still feared trapped.

item.title: Covishield: WHO flags fake jabs in India, Africa
item.description: The health body says it has found counterfeit versions of the Indian-made Covishield vaccine.

item.title: R Kelly trial set to begin in New York
item.description: The singer is accused of racketeering, sexual abuse and bribery; charges which he has denied.

item.title: Cuba tightens control of internet after protests
item.description: Critics say the new rules are aimed at stifling dissent following mass anti-government demonstrations.

item.title: US lab stands on threshold of key nuclear fusion goal
item.description: A US science institute is on the verge of achieving a longstanding goal in nuclear fusion research.

item.title: How technology in the air battles fires on the ground
item.description: Planes equipped with infrared scanners are helping authorities take on historic wildfires in the US.

item.title: Aspirin may help treat aggressive breast cancer
item.description: Doctors hope it could boost the anti-cancer power of other drugs to fight hard-to-treat tumours.

item.title: Snake slithers out of spice shelves at Sydney supermarket
item.description: The python greeted the woman at the spice shelves - luckily, she happened to be a snake rescuer.

item.title: Twitter tests 'misleading' post report button for first time
item.description: Many large social media firms have been accused of not doing enough to fight the spread of disinformation.

item.title: Uncertain times ahead for Afghan women
item.description: After the Taliban takeover, it is not yet clear how women will fare with the militants in power.

item.title: The little-known human stories behind emoji designs
item.description: The surprising story of how some tiny characters ended up on billions of smartphone keyboards.

item.title: How latte art in South Africa led to a job from hell in Oman
item.description: A South African barista was offered a dream opportunity in Oman but unknowingly signed away his freedoms.

item.title: Taliban victory will test India, and peace in South Asia
item.description: How India engages with the Taliban after their rout of Afghanistan could determine the region's fate.

item.title: Biden's speech on Afghanistan fact-checked
item.description: How consistent was President Biden's speech with his previous statements on Afghanistan?

item.title: Just how hard is it to recycle a jumbo jet?
item.description: Thousands of aircraft were left on the tarmac due to Covid, and many will now be broken up for parts.

item.title: Hakainde Hichilema: The Zambian 'cattle boy' who became president
item.description: After six attempts, Hakainde Hichilema has finally become president of Zambia.

item.title: Taliban have been looking for me, says ex-Afghanistan bank governor
item.description: Militants have been knocking on the doors of places he used to live, Ajmal Ahmady says.

item.title: Afghanistan: National flag protesters in Jalalabad appear to be disrupted by gunshots
item.description: Video appears to show protesters waving the country's national flag before fleeing.

item.title: How the Taliban seized Afghanistan again
item.description: Taliban fighters have swept across Afghanistan taking control of towns and cities.

item.title: Taliban: 'We will not allow the soil of Afghanistan to be used against anyone'
item.description: The Taliban have held their first news conference since taking control of Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghan reporter asks Nato secretary general for help
item.description: Lailuma Sadid, a journalist with Brussels Morning Newspaper, became emotional when asking the Nato secretary general about the Taliban in Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan: 'All female staff have left my Kabul hotel'
item.description: The BBC's Malik Mudassir says Taliban fighters are now providing security at his hotel in central Kabul.

item.title: Afghanistan: Mysterious Taliban spokesman finally shows his face
item.description: The spokesman has appeared in public for the first time. But is there more than one Zabihullah Mujahid?

item.title: Afghanistan: Female Kabul resident fears for future under Taliban
item.description: A woman shares her story of the day the Taliban arrived - and why she has lost all hope.

item.title: Afghanistan: What's the impact of Taliban's return on international order?
item.description: What is the diplomatic fallout and how allies and rivals are looking at the US following the Taliban takeover?

item.title: Afghanistan: Striking image captures Kabul exodus
item.description: A photo appears to show hundreds of Afghans packed on a US military plane as they flee the Taliban.
